X made it very clear to him that I was not trying to propose a program of operations.
He understood and appreciated our efforts. After forty minutes X had a pretty
good idea of what he wants and 1 think he benef ited fay some of my ideas and the
experiences of some of the others which X recounted to him. This from a note
of his wraps up his thinking*
"It might be helpful to know that our program policy is built around the idea of
bringing to our audience those kinds of programs that commercial television cannot
afford to do because of the limited interest in the program matter. Chamber
music is one demonstration of this policy. We plan to do specialized programming
for labor unions, bed-ridden students, jjr^Ll businessmen, the foreign born, etc.
Our Intention is to serve a wide series o* selected audiences rather than
attempting to compete with commercial television. We believe that we shall serve
as a supplement to commercial television, providing an alternative program
service that our audience can dip into as they wish.
"I hope this information will be helpful to you in your talks with the AFL leaders
next week. We shall be very interested to hear the results of your talks. As
you very well know, so much of our future success hinges upon good relations with
these television unions. We all wish you the best success.n

a broadcast teacher. He is to meet with the musicians and I promised to give
him a memo on the operation in other cities. IA9s attitude is wrapped up in an
excerpt from a letter which I received from him in Miami*

broadcasting operation and that they will consider us (except where commercial
money is involved) in a special category by which the bare minimum of union
